content: The crime is hideous, and if found guilty, he should be strung up by his thumbs ... or perhaps some part(s) of his anatomy that is (are) more sensitive to pain. Regardless, the fact that he is a Soldier is irrelevant. He could be a postal worker, truck driver, doctor, lawyer, mason, electrician, burger-flipper, teacher, clerk, CPA, whatever. Citing the guy's job is just sensationalizing the crime - as if it needed that.

content: As for the topic, IF he is guilty, he should get whatever the law allows him to receive, no slap on the wrist. By the sound of it, it does not state if the 12 year old (not that I am condoning this) and the Soldier had a relationship going on. I would like to know because if so, then the parents knew something as well. Or were remiss in the parental duties to protect their child. I could be wrong of course. Todays politics remind me of an old saying. - "Ideas are more powerful than guns. We would not let our enemies have guns, why should we let them have ideas?" - Joseph Stalin

content: The article does not state she was raped. The guy is charged with having sex with a minor under the age of 16, carnel knowlege. Kids as young as 12 are having sex today. What it comes down to is, this NCO can kiss his career goodbye and some free time. We don't need NCOs like this guy, not only does he disgrace the NCO corps but the army as a whole.

content: quote: The second offense allegedly occurred in March, when Gaskins - who had been reassigned to a unit in Naples - was invited to stay in the guest room of a fellow Soldier after a night of drinking. I gather there was more than one instance? Could it be that she approached him one or more times while he was drunk? It does seem he may have been taken advantage of while in that state. I know I have done some things while drunk, that I would never do if sober (think coyote ugly)..... What if he was passed out and she did the deed? What then, assuming he was passed out?
